Context:
The college offers a Networking and Information Technology program with two specializations: Networking and Systems. The Networking specialization focuses on network administration, wireless LANs, and prepares students for Cisco CCNA Routing & Switching certification and other related industry certifications. The Systems specialization covers mail server administration, content management systems, database administration, computer security, and infrastructure virtualization.

The program involves real-life projects or case studies in the third year, which may be completed independently or with an industry partner or the college's Office of Research and Innovation. Students have worked on IT solutions for hospitals, corporations, and service providers like Bell Mobility, Rogers Communications, Cogeco Data Systems, etc.

The curriculum covers all courses of the official Cisco CCNA Routing & Switching curriculum. It also prepares students to write examinations leading to other industry certifications like the Certified Wireless Network Administrator (CWNA) and Cisco Certified CyberOps Associate. The college invests in up-to-date networking, wireless, radio frequency, VoIP, and security lab equipment for hands-on experience.

Students starting in the winter term will be required to attend classes during the summer months. Technology requirements include a personal computer with 16 GB RAM minimum, 256 GB SSD Hard Drive (500+ GB is optimal), Quad-core i7 2.4GHz or better processor, video card with 2GB RAM minimum/4GB RAM recommended, and a webcam.

Transfer credits toward further study to attain a degree are available for students.

Required courses for the first semester include COMP 1151.

- Once a specialization is picked in semester five, students won't be able to change in semester six.

Semester 6 Courses:

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate will be able to:
1. Identify, analyze, design, develop, implement, verify and document the requirements for a computing environment.
2. Diagnose, troubleshoot, document and monitor technical problems using appropriate methodologies and tools.
3. Analyze, design, implement and maintain secure computing environments.
4. Analyze, develop and maintain robust computing system solutions through validation testing and industry best practices.
5. Communicate and collaborate with team members and stakeholders to ensure effective working relationship.
6. Select and apply strategies for personal and professional development to enhance work performance.
7. Apply project management principles and tools when responding to requirements and monitoring projects within a computing environment.
8. Adhere to ethical, social media, legal, regulatory and economic requirements and/or principles in the development and management of the computing solutions and systems.
9. Investigate emerging trends to respond to technical challenges.
10. Analyze, plan, design, implement and administer computer systems and cloud solutions.
11. Research, design, deploy, configure, troubleshoot, maintain, upgrade and decommission computing system infrastructures.
12. Select and apply scripting tools and programming languages to automate routine tasks.
13. Install, monitor, optimize and administer a database management system in response to specified requirements.
14. Design, implement and administer technical support processes for computing system infrastructures that aligns with industry best practice.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,145.00 *
- International Tuition: $18,350.00 **

* This is the tuition fee for domestic students only. No additional information about this fee was provided in the text.
** The tuition fee for international students is significantly higher than that of domestic students. No further details were given about this fee or any other potential additional costs mentioned at the end of the text.

Context: The Computer Systems Technology program is offered through the School of Computer Technology at George Brown College from the Casa Loma Campus located at 146 Kendal Avenue in Toronto. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and can contact the School of Computer Technology office using phone number 416-415-5000, ext. 4287 or email computertechnology@georgebrown.ca during office hours Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m. The Program Co-ordinator is Jorge Olenewa and can be reached at phone number 416-415-5000, ext. 6809 or email jolenewa@georgebrown.ca. For more information about George Brown College and related programs like Computer Programming and Analysis (T177), Computer Systems Technician (T141), and Cyber Security (Postgraduate) (T433), interested individuals can sign up for an information session or campus tour, book a virtual meeting with international recruitment representatives, or explore the virtual tour on the college's website.
